abstract.p: The adoption of a numerical method to perform vibration and acoustic analyses is attracting increasing attention because of its merits in saving costs and time. The analysis flow chart of structure-borne noise reduction by controlling the vehicle body panel vibration is proposed. A finite element analysis of a body in white is performed according to this flow chart, using MSC. Nastran, and the experimental modal analysis of a body in white is also carried out. To verify the finite element model, a correlation analysis between the test and the finite element results is performed. After the acoustic boundary element model with seats has been constructed, the acoustic transfer vector is calculated using LMS software. A transfer path analysis is performed to estimate the powertrain and exhaust pipe operational forces at idle. Then the forces are input into the acoustic boundary element model to calculate the body panel velocity. By combining the acoustic transfer vector and the body panel velocity, the interior acoustic response can be obtained. The simulation results are verified by tests. To determine the main contribution panels for the interior sound pressure level, a panel acoustic contribution analysis is based on the boundary element method. Finally, constrained damping treatments are adopted to control the main panel vibration based on the results of the panel acoustic contribution analysis. The test results indicate that the sound pressure level of the interior noise at idle is reduced obviously before and after treatments, which has proved the correctness of the results from the panel acoustic contribution analysis. Therefore it is believed that the proposed analysis method is feasible for reducing interior structure-borne noise.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Nowadays, one of the most valuable criteria for vehicle quality assessment is based on acoustic emission levels; the comfort of a car depends on the noise level transmitted inside it. Consequently, there is general attention to design criteria aimed at improving the structural–acoustic behaviour in such a way that the increasingly restrictive ergonomic standards1 are adhered to. Interior noise can be divided into airborne noise and structure-borne noise according to their transmission modes. Usually the noise below 500 Hz is mainly transmitted by the structure or the solid parts of the car. The structure-borne noise can be reduced by controlling the noise sources or their transfer paths.

In a structure-borne analysis the frequency range of interest below 200 Hz is determined by the major sources of the input energy. It is well known that the powertrain is the main vehicle noise and vibration source below the speed of 120 km/h. The powertrain at idle and its harmonics are subject to strong excitation of frequencies below 200 Hz according to Mohanty et al.2 The objective of this study is to reduce the interior structure-borne noise by controlling the body panel vibration without adjusting the powertrain mount system and the suspension system.

The structure-borne noise can be studied by numerical methodologies such as the boundary element method (BEM) and the finite element method (FEM) which are effective up to medium frequencies.1 The combined usage of the BEM and the FEM is becoming increasingly popular for vibro-acoustic analysis, with the FEM to be preferred for the structural dynamic simulation and the BEM for the acoustic field assessment.1–8 This combined approach provides results that are useful for planning active and passive design adjustments to minimize the structure-borne noise that is transmitted inside the car body, so as to avoid very costly experimental campaigns.

Analysis methods and a flow chart for structure-borne noise reduction by controlling the body panel vibration are proposed in the present study. The FEM is used to calculate the structural characteristics of the body in white (BIW), and the correlation between the FE and the test results is demonstrated. After the acoustic boundary element model with seats has been constructed, the acoustic transfer vector (ATV) is calculated.

A transfer path analysis (TPA) is performed to estimate the powertrain and exhaust pipe operational forces at idle. Then the forces are input into the acoustic BEM to calculate the body panel velocity. By combining the ATV and the body panel velocity, the interior acoustic response can be achieved. The simulation results are verified by tests. To demonstrate which panels make the main contributions to the interior sound pressure level (SPL), a panel acoustic contribution analysis (PACA) is carried out on the basis of the BEM. Finally, constrained damping treatments are adopted to control the panel vibration based on the PACA results, and the test results verify the correctness of the PACA.

sec.title: Analysis method of structure-borne noise reduction by controlling the body panel vibration
Analysis flow chart of structure-borne noise
sec.p: If we consider the cavity enclosed inside a car body, the boundary structural vibrations generate pressure variations in the fluid mass, causing the internal noise phenomenon. The dynamic response of a fluid mass inside a cavity is activated by the car body’s structural modes but, at the same time, fluid resonance can influence the structure’s dynamic behaviour; this means that, in general, a fluid–structure coupled analysis (structure-borne noise such as booming is due to the coupling between the structural vibration and the interior sound pressure fluctuations) is required. When the fluid is air and its acoustic modes are not coincident with the structural modes, it is possible, in a first approximation, to neglect such interactions.

In this work, only a ‘weak coupling’ between the fluid and the structure was considered (the structure dynamics are not influenced by the fluid), so that the problem dynamics can be separately calculated by the FEM while the BEM can be used in a later phase for the fluid acoustic assessment.

To predict and control the interior noise, an analysis flow chart of structure-borne noise reduction based on the FEM–BEM method is proposed, as shown in Figure 1. First, the finite element (FE) of the BIW is modelled. To determine the whole modes and the important local modes, an FE analysis of the BIW is performed, and an experimental modal analysis of the BIW is also carried out. The correlation analysis between the FE results and the test results is performed to verify the FE model. Then, the excitation forces obtained from the TPA are loaded at the specific locations (the powertrain mounts and the exhaust pipe hangers) of the BIW to obtain the body’s velocity response as the boundary conditions of the PACA. Also, the boundary element model of a body with seats is constructed. After setting up field points in the BEM, the ATVs can be calculated. Then, to indicate the direction for body panel improvement, the PACA of the peak frequencies at the interior locations is carried out by combining the body’s velocity responses and the ATVs. Finally, constrained damping treatments are adopted to control the body panel vibration based on the PACA results and the improvement in the interior noise is verified by the test results.

ATVs can be interpreted as an ensemble of acoustic transfer functions from the surface nodes to a single field point and they depend only on the configuration of the acoustic domain, i.e. the geometry and properties (the speed of sound and the density), on the acoustic surface treatment, on the frequency and on the field point; they do not depend on the loading conditions and the structural response.

The velocity of the body panel vibration varies with different driving conditions. The acoustic response is calculated for all loading conditions by combining the ATVs with the normal structural velocity boundary condition vectors. However, the acoustic transfer function is evaluated from the radiating surface to the specific field point for the involved frequency range, without taking into account the actual loading conditions. When the acoustic domain has not been changed, to shorten the time for solving the acoustic response and to improve the analysis efficiency, we could use ATV technology to predict the acoustic response in different driving conditions.

sec.title: Experimental modal analysis of the BIW
Test system
sec.p: The test system consists of three parts: the exciter system, the data acquisition system and the modal analysis and process system. The exciter system includes the QDAC signal generator module of the LMS SCADAS III SC316W system, power amplifiers and shakers. The data acquisition system includes acceleration transducers, force transducers and the LMS SCADAS III SC316W signal amplification and acquisition system. The software used in the modal analysis is LMS Test.Lab. An illustration of the whole system is shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the modal test system.

sec.title: Test method
sec.p: The ‘multiple input–multiple output’ method is adopted in the modal test. 145 measuring points in three directions are measured in the modal test. The geometry of the BIW in LMS Test.Lab is shown in Figure 3. FE calculations of the BIW show that the transverse (Y) and vertical (Z) modes are the main modes, while the longitudinal (X) modes in the low-frequency range are the minor modes. Therefore, in order to ensure that the transverse and vertical modes are adequately excited, two points in the Z direction and one point in the Y direction are selected as the driving points, as shown in Figure 3. From Figure 4 it is seen that the tested BIW is suspended by elastic ropes to ensure a suspension frequency below 10% of the first mode of the BIW.

sec.title: Correlation analysis between the test model and the finite element model
sec.p: Correlation analysis can help to quantify the geometrical and dynamic (frequency response function and modal) resemblance between the test model and its FE equivalent model. For modal analysis, this means the degree of correlation between the modal parameters of the FE model and the test model. In general, the test model is always considered more reliable. Therefore the correlation analysis is often used to evaluate and to improve the accuracy of theoretical models. The related criteria of modal analysis mainly include the frequency criterion, the modal assurance criterion (MAC), the coordinate modal assurance criterion, the frequency response assurance criterion and the response vector assurance criterion.10 For modal analysis, the first concern is the modal frequencies and the modal shapes.

sec.title: Mesh preparation
sec.p: Building the mesh is the first step in using the BEM to solve a problem. Usually, a structural FE mesh is used as a starting point for creating the boundary element mesh. Sometimes a boundary element mesh can be obtained by simply ‘skinning’ the structural FE mesh. However, the structural FE mesh is often excessively fine for the subsequent acoustic boundary element analyses, leading to excessive central processing unit time. Commercially available software packages have been developed to skin and then to coarsen structural FE meshes. These packages can automatically remove one-dimensional elements such as bars and beams and can skin three-dimensional elements such as tetrahedra with two-dimensional boundary elements. Then, the skinned model can be coarsened, providing the user with the desired BEM mesh. The shell elements are typically used in the FE element preprocessor, and the nodes and elements are transferred to the boundary element software. The material properties and thicknesses of the elements are irrelevant since the boundary elements only bound the domain.

sec.title: Seat
sec.p: Because the existence of the seat has a great influence on the results of the boundary element model,6 the seats are included in the BEM. They mainly affect the geometry and acoustic treatment characteristics of the body cavity.
First, the computer-aided design model of three rows of seats is modelled by using CATIA software. Then the seat models are meshed in Hypermesh, as shown in Figure 6.

caption.p: FE model of the seat.

sec.title: Cavity
sec.p: To obtain the boundary element model of the cavity, the FE model of a seat, five doors and windows should be added to the BIW model using Hypermesh software. The model is meshed using shell elements including quadrilateral and triangular elements. Table 3 shows the material parameters of the four doors and windows used in the FE model.

caption.p: The material parameters of four doors and windows.

sec.p: Then a BEM mesh of the cavity is created automatically by using the LMS Virtual.Lab Cavity Meshing product by taking the skin of the FEM cavity mesh. Through the LMS’s automatic mesh generator, an acoustic FE model of 80 mm mesh size is developed. According to the principle that there are at least six linear elements in a wavelength,7 the upper analysed frequency will reach 708.3 Hz. This frequency can meet the research requirements of the present paper. The acoustic boundary element model with seats is shown in Figure 7.

caption.p: Acoustic boundary element modelling.

sec.p: The direction of the element normal to the surface is another important aspect of mesh preparation. The element normal direction is determined by the sequence of the nodes defining a particular element. If the direct BEM is used, the normal direction should point towards or away from the acoustic domain depending on the convention used by the BEM software. In most instances, adjusting the normal direction is trivial since LMS software has the built-in smarts to reverse the normal direction of a mesh or to make the normal direction consistent.

sec.title: ATV calculation
sec.p: After the mesh is defined, the fluid properties for the acoustic domain can be specified. The BEM assumes that the fluid is a homogeneous ideal fluid in the linear regime. The fluid properties consist of the speed of sound and the mean density. The passenger compartment shown in Figure 7 could be modelled as two separate acoustic domains: one for the air and another for the seat. The material properties of the seat are the complex density and speed of sound of the seat material. Based on the above, the properties of the material wrapping the body structure are taken to be those of air, while the seat material is usually foam. The physical properties of the foam are as follows: the complex speed of sound is 66 + 24i m/s and the complex acoustic density is 19 – 11i kg/m3. The air is assumed to be conservative so that its physical properties are real and consequently the solution is real. For the acoustic analysis, the modelled air properties are given in Table 4.

caption.p: The properties of air in the BEM.

sec.p: Before ATV calculation, the location of the driver’s right ear (DRE) is set to the field point. Since the air space of the passenger compartment is modally dense, a fine frequency resolution of 1 Hz was used.

The frequency range of interest in the ATV calculation is 20–200 Hz. The ATV calculation results at the DRE are shown in Figure 8. The ATV results are expressed as contours, and the different colours of the element correspond to the ATV values.

caption.p: ATV calculation results at the DRE : (a) 27 Hz; (b) 54 Hz; (c) 118 Hz; (d) 135 Hz.
ATV: acoustic transfer vector.

sec.title: Interior structure-borne noise analysis
sec.p: The acoustic response calculation has three steps: first, computation of the ATV by the BEM as carried out in the section on ATV calculation, then, determination of the body panel velocity under the operational force input by the FEM and, finally, calculation of the pressure response within the acoustic domain based on the boundary velocity information and the ATV.

sec.title: Structural frequency response analysis
sec.p: The excitations for the velocity response using the FEM are the forces on the cab side of the mounts such as the powertrain mounts and the exhaust pipe hangers. This velocity response is then translated into a boundary condition for the prediction of the interior SPL by the BEM.

sec.title: Operational force calculation at idle
sec.p: The engine idle condition is studied in the present paper. The transfer of the (X, Y, Z) three translational degrees of freedom (DOFs) of the exciting force of the engine mount is considered and the moment transfer of the rotational DOFs is ignored. Thus there are nine transfer paths for three points in the engine mount. We assume that the force transmissions of the above paths affect each other. It is advisable to consider these cross-coupling effects. For the exhaust pipe hangers, because the exciting forces in the X and the Y directions have less influence on the interior noise, the forces in the Z direction are considered. Similar to the engine mounts, we assume that the force transmissions of the four hangers also affect each other, as shown in Figure 9. The matrix inversion method12 is used to identify the exciting forces.

caption.p: The configuration of the exhaust pipe hanger system.

sec.p: The test plans for the TPA are as follows.

list-item.p: Two triaxial accelerators should be installed on the body side of each powertrain mount. A hammer is used to impact the body side (as close to the connection points as possible) of each mount in the X, Y and Z directions. At the same time the force signal and the acceleration signal should be recorded.

Two one-way accelerators should be installed on the body side of each exhaust pipe hanger. A hammer is used to impact vertically the body side (as close to the connection points as possible) of each hanger in the Z direction. At the same time the force signal and the acceleration signal should be recorded.
The engine should be switched on and then warmed up for a period of 20 min. After the engine idle condition is stable, each accelerator signal should be recorded.
A microphone should be installed at the DRE to measure the acoustic pressure at idle.

sec.title: The body panel velocity under the operational force input
sec.p: The powertrain mount system in the present study is a standard drive type with the characteristics of a longitudinal engine, three-point support and rear-axle drive. The primary paths of the structural energy into the cab at idle include three powertrain mounts and four exhaust pipe hangers. These mounts and hangers are used to provide vibration isolation for the cab by reducing the transmission of energy into the cab. To predict the structure-borne noise caused by the powertrain mounts and the exhaust pipe hangers, the operational forces at idle are applied to the locations of these mounts and hangers. The body panel velocity response is shown in Figure 11.

caption.p: Body panel velocity response: (a) 27 Hz; (b) 54 Hz; (c) 118 Hz; (d) 135 Hz.

sec.title: Interior acoustic prediction due to structural excitations
sec.p: After calculating the velocity response of the structure, the BEM can be used to evaluate the pressure response within the acoustic domain.

This body velocity response in the section on the structural frequency response analysis is translated into a boundary element in the section on the ATV calculation for the prediction of the interior SPL at the DRE. Comparisons of the simulation and the test results of the interior SPL are shown in Figure 12. Although the boundary element results do not exactly match the measured results, the trends are predicted well and the overall SPL values are quite close.

caption.p: Acoustic prediction at the DRE due to structural excitation at the powertrain mounts and the exhaust pipe hangers.
SPL: sound pressure level.

sec.p: It is found to be very difficult to predict the acoustic response accurately from the product research and development practice and from the literature. Normally, if the trend match is good, it can help the automotive engineer to perform troubleshooting. The reason for amplitude errors between the tests and the simulation could be analysed. The influence of other structure-borne paths such as the chassis mounts (e.g. the strut tops) can be excluded because only the idle condition considered here. The discrepancy between the tests and the simulation could be explained as follows. First, there is no velocity information on the door in the boundary analysis because the four doors are not included in the FE model. Second, the airborne noise is included in the tests but not in the simulation. The medium-frequency noise and the high-frequency noise can be easily transmitted into the cabin because of their relatively short wavelengths. Third, the sound-absorbing material is not considered in the model.

The engine in the present study is a gasoline engine with four cylinders in a line and a four-stroke cycle. The engine speed at idle is 800 r/min. Therefore the fundamental frequency is 13.33 Hz and the main excitation frequencies for this type of engine are the even orders. It can be seen from the figure that the main peak frequencies of the interior SPL are 27 Hz (second order), 54 Hz (fourth order), 80 Hz (sixth order), 118 Hz (no order) and 135 Hz (tenth order). In addition to 118 Hz, the noise spectrum reflects the significant features of the harmonics.

It is seen from the definition of the acoustic contribution coefficient that there are positive, negative and neutral acoustic contributions. If the phase angle difference between a panel pressure and the total pressure is less than 90°, the panel or element contributes to the total amount in a positive way. The total pressure increases with increasing number of contributions. If the phase angle difference between a panel pressure and the total pressure is more than 90°, the panel or element contributes to the total amount in a negative way. This type of contribution actually reduces the total pressure. If the phase angle difference between a panel pressure and the total pressure is close to 90° or the panel pressure amplitude is small, the panel or element contributes to the total amount in a neutral way. A panel with a neutral contribution cannot be modified to achieve the desired objectives. Therefore it is very important to identify the positive and negative acoustic contributions for noise reduction before structural modifications.

sec.title: Test verification
sec.p: In order to verify the accuracy of the PACA in the last section, the vibration of panel 17 (right_rear side wall) is controlled since this panel contributes to the sound pressure at 54 Hz and 135 Hz at idle in a positive way. The SPLs before and after modifications are compared.

Improving the structure stiffness and the damping are two ways to suppress the vibration of the body panel. In theory, the damping treatment should not change the natural frequencies of the body panel. It only increases the damping in the resonance area when the body panel is excited by a source with the same frequency. Because of the high damping characteristics of viscoelastic materials, the damping treatment in the structure can lower the resonant response in a very broad frequency range and generally does not have significant additional peaks. Therefore the damping treatment is more suitable for verifying the PACA conclusions in this section.

Because a constrained damping treatment can dissipate more energy and can be achieved more conveniently than the free damping treatment,8 it is used to reduce the panel vibration. The substrate materials and constrained layers for this are butyl rubber and aluminium sheet.

Based on the PACA results, a constrained damping treatment is imposed on panel 17, as shown in Figure 14. The right_rear side wall acceleration after the damping treatment is shown in Figure 15. It is seen from the figure that the panel vibration is reduced obviously, especially in the frequency range 100–160 Hz.

caption.p: Constrained damping treatment of right_rear side wall.
Right_rear side wall acceleration after the constrained damping treatment.

sec.p: The SPL at the DRE after the constrained damping treatment is shown in Figure 16. From the figure it is seen that the interior SPL at certain frequencies decreases obviously, e.g. 2.0 dB reduction at 54 Hz, and 7.4 dB reduction at 135 Hz. This conclusion is consistent with the PACA conclusions that panel 17 contributes to the above frequencies in a positive way.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In the present study the FEM–BEM method is adopted to study the mini-bus structure-borne noise. An analysis method and flow chart for structure-borne noise reduction by controlling the body panel vibration is proposed and verified by tests. The research work and conclusions are as follows.

list-item.p: The FE of the BIW is modelled and the body structure modes are calculated. The correlation analysis between the FE and the test results shows that the relative errors of the frequency of the FE model and the test model are small and that the modal shapes of the FE model and the test model agree well, which has proved the reliability of the FE model.
The acoustic boundary element model with seats is constructed. The location of the DRE is set to the field point, and the ATV in the frequency range 20–200 Hz is calculated using LMS software.

The matrix inversion method is used to estimate the powertrain and the exhaust pipe operational forces at idle. Then the forces are input into the acoustic BEM to calculate the body panel velocity. By combining the ATV and the body panel velocity, the interior acoustic response can be obtained. Comparison between the simulation and test results indicates that the main peak frequencies are more consistent with the same trend.

The BE model of the cab is split into 22 panels and a PACA is made on the basis of the formulae. The PACA results indicate the panels that mainly contribute to the peak values of the SPL. By imposing a constrained damping treatment on the right_rear side wall, the panel vibration and the interior SPL are obviously reduced, which further verifies the correctness of the PACA conclusions.

sec.p: The analysis method of structure-borne noise reduction is studied and the test results show that the interior SPLs are reduced significantly. Therefore this analysis method and flow chart are expected to help automotive sound engineers to reduce interior structure-borne noise.
